awd_titl_txt: Molecular Analysis of Gene Products Required for            Gastrulation
awd_abstract_narration: Gastrulation and dorsal-ventral axis formation in Drosophila are                interrelated processes which result from a complex hierarchy of                 maternal and zygotic gene interactions. The product of a gene                   essential for these processes, the maternally expressed                         gastrulation defective (gd) gene has been partially                             characterized. The gd gene encodes three proteins present only in               ovaries and early embryos. These could arise through                            transcriptional or translational regulation. The former                         possibility will be examined by nuclease protection analysis of                 gd transcripts and the latter by metabolic labeling studies and                 by immunoaffinity purifying and physically characterizing the                   three proteins. In addition, the effect of mutations in other                   genes affecting dorsal-ventral polarity on the gd proteins will                 be investigated.                                                                %%%                                                                             The body plan of the Drosophila larva is generated progressively                during early stages of embryogenesis through an interacting                     hierarchy of gene products. Dr. Konrad will characterize one of                 these genes which will help to define the overall hierarchy of                  control.
